sub_topic: Finding the chromatic polynomial of a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following graph: 

![Graph Image](https://i.imgur.com/5A5fw5x.png)

Find the chromatic polynomial of this graph.
message_2:
To find the chromatic polynomial of the given graph, we can use the deletion-contraction algorithm. Let's label the vertices as A, B, C, D, and E, as shown below:

```
A -- B -- C
|         |
E -- D -- C
```

Now, let's consider the edge connecting vertices B and C. We will delete this edge and contract this edge separately and find the chromatic polynomial for each resulting graph.

1. Deletion: Remove the edge BC.

```
A -- B    C
|         |
E -- D -- C
```

The chromatic polynomial of this graph is P(G - e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-3).

2. Contraction: Merge vertices B and C into a single vertex, say X, and remove the edge BC.

```
A -- X
|    |
E -- D
```

The chromatic polynomial of this graph is P(G / e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2).

Now, we can find the chromatic polynomial of the original graph using the deletion-contraction formula:

P(G, k) = P(G - e, k) - P(G / e, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-3) - k(k-1)(k-2) = k(k-1)(k-2)[(k-3) - 1] = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-4).

So, the chromatic polynomial of the given graph is P(G, k) = k(k-1)(k-2)(k-4).
